issue.title: Updated picnic to v.2.1.2
issue.body: Updated picnic code from v.2.1.1 to v.2.1.2, addresses issue #588.

issue.title: Integrate Picnic latest changes
issue.body: Integrate updates to Picnic 2.1.2 tag, and the more recent changes.

issue.title: docker added
issue.body:
Enabled all (remaining) images to run docker. If OK, please also push resultant images to `openquantumsafe` (dockerhub).

I'll follow up with a PR for an automated CircleCI image-test-build-push config in `oqs-demos` using these images. For the final auto-push to work seamlessly, please [install a CircleCI context](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/contexts/) `openquantumsafe` with `DOCKER_LOGIN` and `DOCKER_PASSWORD` environment variables correctly set.

comment.body:
> For the final auto-push to work seamlessly, please [install a CircleCI context](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/contexts/) `openquantumsafe` with `DOCKER_LOGIN` and `DOCKER_PASSWORD` environment variables correctly set.

Is there a way to do it with access tokens rather than having to put my Docker username and password in those environment variables?

issue.title: docker added
issue.body:
Enabled all (remaining) images to run docker. If OK, please also push resultant images to `openquantumsafe` (dockerhub).

I'll follow up with a PR for an automated CircleCI image-test-build-push config in `oqs-demos` using these images. For the final auto-push to work seamlessly, please [install a CircleCI context](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/contexts/) `openquantumsafe` with `DOCKER_LOGIN` and `DOCKER_PASSWORD` environment variables correctly set.

comment.body:
Yes: Storing an access token as value in DOCKER_PASSWORD works identically.

 

From: Douglas Stebila <notifications@github.com>
Reply to: open-quantum-safe/ci-containers <reply@reply.github.com>
Date: Tuesday, 10 March 2020 at 03:09
To: open-quantum-safe/ci-containers <ci-containers@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Michael Baentsch <info@baentsch.ch>, Author <author@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [open-quantum-safe/ci-containers] docker added (#38)

 

For the final auto-push to work seamlessly, please install a CircleCI context openquantumsafe with DOCKER_LOGIN and DOCKER_PASSWORD environment variables correctly set.

Is there a way to do it with access tokens rather than having to put my Docker username and password in those environment variables?

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.

> Currently working on adding Falcon

Hi, Is there an update on this?  Using Library and Falcon is only signature scheme currently missing.

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body: We have been having some discussions internally for a while about how to approach this.  @baentsch and @xvzcf have been leading the investigation, maybe they can chip in here about what they've been planning.

issue.title: Fixing BIKE compilation on an AVX512 supporting platform
issue.body:
This PR fixes the compilation for BIKE in the following scenarios:
1) When using Clang-3.9
2) When running on an AVX512 platform

It also fixes a "missing new line" warning for a qtesla header.

Note that the compilation of LibOQS (with clang-3.9) still fails due to the flag "-Wno-unguarded-availability-new" (in picnic) that is not recognized by clang-3.9.

comment.body:
Thanks @drucker-nir!

@xvzcf note that this might affect #652.
Still on my list of things to do, hopefully this week!

comment.body: I'll check if this code is actually supported on macOS (I suppose the circleCI mac VMs didn't support avx2, so this code wasn't triggered?); if not, I'll revert back to non-avx2 processing on macOS. I hope to get to this this afternoon, as to not have the master branch failing.

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

issue.title: Fixing BIKE compilation on an AVX512 supporting platform
issue.body:
This PR fixes the compilation for BIKE in the following scenarios:
1) When using Clang-3.9
2) When running on an AVX512 platform

It also fixes a "missing new line" warning for a qtesla header.

Note that the compilation of LibOQS (with clang-3.9) still fails due to the flag "-Wno-unguarded-availability-new" (in picnic) that is not recognized by clang-3.9.

comment.body: Removed my comment since I misread a line.

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body: I can add the C++ compilers to the CI images, which I've been meaning to look at anyway since some packages installed there (like `xsltproc` or `graphviz`) might be unnecessary.

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body: @xvzcf Thanks in advance for the CI image updates! Regarding copying `cpu_features`, I'm not sure: The guys have an open bug (regarding shared lib building) and it kind of would be nice if the fix at some point automatically flows into `liboqs` instead of us having to copy the new fixed version in.

issue.title: Compilation failure in Picnic on macOS
issue.body:
When I try to locally compile liboqs after #650 landed, I get the follow compilation error:

